G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; and G.L. c. 215, § 6, as this Court previously issued the custody and parenting-time orders at issue, and the children reside in Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; and G.L. c. 215, § 6, as this Court previously issued the custody and parenting-time orders at issue, and the children reside in Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; and G.L. c. 215, § 6, as this Court previously issued the custody and parenting-time orders at issue, and the children reside in Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue in the Bristol County Probate and Family Court is proper pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1 and applicable Massachusetts domestic relations law, as the parties and the children reside in Bristol County and the original Judgment/Order was entered in this Court.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: In addition, Massachusetts law requires that the “paramount concern” in any custody or parenting‑time determination be the best interests of the child.

*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.proposition: The Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have consistently held that a significant change in the work schedule or living circumstances of a custodial or non‑custodial parent can constitute the requisite material change of circumstances warranting modification.
*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.support_reasoning: The case is a divorce and removal case decided in the context of an initial divorce judgment, not a post‑judgment modification proceeding. The opinion does not discuss the standard for modifying existing custody or support orders, nor does it address what constitutes a “material change of circumstances,” let alone link that concept to changes in work schedules or living circumstances. Instead, the court applies the best‑interests and “real advantage” standards under the removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30, at the time of the original custody determination.
*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents… shall not… be removed out of this commonwealth… unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.”

Custody of a Minor (No. 1), 377 Mass. 87.proposition: The Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have consistently held that a significant change in the work schedule or living circumstances of a custodial or non‑custodial parent can constitute the requisite material change of circumstances warranting modification.
Custody of a Minor (No. 1), 377 Mass. 87.support_reasoning: The opinion is a care-and-protection case about parental unfitness and the standard of proof for removing a child from parental custody under G.L. c. 119. It does not concern modification of prior custody or visitation orders, nor does it discuss material change of circumstances, work schedules, or living arrangements in the context of modification. Accordingly, it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition that a significant change in work schedule or living circumstances constitutes a material change warranting modification.
Custody of a Minor (No. 1), 377 Mass. 87.relevant_excerpt: Pursuant to the statutory provision creating the action, G. L. c. 119, § 24… any person concerned for a child’s welfare may file a petition… alleging that the child "is without necessary and proper physical, educational or moral care and discipline…" If the court finds the allegations proved, the judge may commit the child to the department… While there may have been some question in prior years regarding the kinds of evidence sufficient to prove cases… it is now clear that the Commonwealth may not attempt to force the breakup of a natural family without an affirmative showing of parental unfitness.

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have consistently held that a significant change in the work schedule or living circumstances of a custodial or non‑custodial parent can constitute the requisite material change of circumstances warranting modification.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion in Custody of Kali does not address modification standards or what constitutes a ‘material’ or ‘substantial’ change of circumstances. The discussion of work schedules and living arrangements occurs only in the context of an initial custody determination under the ‘best interests of the child’ standard, not in deciding whether a prior order should be modified. The court expressly declines to apply or analyze the G. L. c. 209C, § 20 substantial‑change standard, so the case cannot be cited as authority that changes in work schedule or living circumstances constitute the requisite material change warranting modification.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a). … It is clear from the record that the case in the Probate Court was tried under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), not G. L. c. 209C, § 20….”}

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: The Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have consistently held that a significant change in the work schedule or living circumstances of a custodial or non‑custodial parent can constitute the requisite material change of circumstances warranting modification.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The case is a removal/relocation decision, not a modification case turning on a threshold “material change of circumstances” analysis. The opinion focuses on interpreting G.L. c. 208, § 30 and applying a best‑interests standard in a joint physical custody context; it does not discuss what constitutes a material change of circumstances for purposes of modifying custody or parenting plans, nor does it treat a changed work schedule or living circumstances as that kind of threshold showing. The quoted ALI Principles passage about relocation constituting a substantial change is descriptive/secondary, not an adoption of a Massachusetts rule on material change for modification proceedings.

Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 89 Mass. App.raw_text: Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 89 Mass. App. Ct. 208 (2016)
Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 89 Mass. App.proposition: The Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have consistently held that a significant change in the work schedule or living circumstances of a custodial or non‑custodial parent can constitute the requisite material change of circumstances warranting modification.
Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 89 Mass. App.support_reasoning: The quoted opinion is not Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser; it is a criminal case (Commonwealth v. Henderson) dealing with leaving the scene of an accident and double jeopardy concerns. It does not address custody, modification standards, or material changes in work schedules or living circumstances. Therefore, this opinion cannot support the claimed family‑law proposition about material changes of circumstances for custody modification.
Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 89 Mass. App.relevant_excerpt: “On appeal, the defendant maintains that (1) the judge erred in failing to instruct that the Commonwealth must prove that he had the specific intent to leave the scene of the accident, and (2) he was convicted of multiple counts of leaving the scene of an accident in violation of his right to be free from double jeopardy.”

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981) (rescript)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have consistently held that a significant change in the work schedule or living circumstances of a custodial or non‑custodial parent can constitute the requisite material change of circumstances warranting modification.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns initial custody determination and the requirement that custody awards be based on the child’s welfare and appropriate findings. It does not discuss modification standards, material change in circumstances, or changes in a parent’s work schedule or living situation as grounds for modification. Therefore it does not provide authority for the claimed proposition about material changes warranting modification.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied)… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed.”

Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.raw_text: Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865 (2006)
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.proposition: The Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have consistently held that a significant change in the work schedule or living circumstances of a custodial or non‑custodial parent can constitute the requisite material change of circumstances warranting modification.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal case under G.L. c. 208, § 30, not a custody-modification case turning on work schedule or living-circumstance changes. The only modification issue discussed is whether the mother’s post‑divorce remarriage is a material and substantial change in circumstances under G.L. c. 208, § 28; the court does not articulate any general rule that significant changes in a parent’s work schedule or living circumstances, as such, constitute the requisite material change. Thus it does not provide authority for the broad proposition stated.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.relevant_excerpt: “He concluded from this that any change in circumstances occurred prior to the divorce, and therefore did not justify a modification. His ruling is inconsistent with G. L. c. 208, § 28 … ‘[u]pon a complaint after a divorce …, the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment … provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred….’ … In the present case, the mother’s marriage is plainly a material and substantial change in circumstances occurring subsequent to the date of divorce.”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: The Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have consistently held that a significant change in the work schedule or living circumstances of a custodial or non‑custodial parent can constitute the requisite material change of circumstances warranting modification.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses what can constitute a material and substantial change of circumstances for custody modification, but it does not hold that a significant change in work schedule or living circumstances is such a change. In fact, it expressly says the mother’s hectic work schedule and later improvements in that schedule did not warrant modification, and that the child’s increased time in Northborough (a change in living arrangements) resulting from a temporary order likewise could not form the basis for a custody change. The case thus undercuts, rather than supports, the broad proposition asserted.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “We note, first, that a parent who works outside the home, even one with a ‘hectic’ schedule, may still be the appropriate primary caretaker and that, standing alone, such employment would not warrant a custody modification. Second, by the time of trial, the probate judge found that positive changes in the mother’s work schedule ‘allowed her to spend more time with the minor child.’ Thus, to the extent that changes in the mother’s work schedule did occur, they were not changes warranting a modification in the custody arrangement.”

M.C. v. T.K., 463 Mass. 226 (2012).proposition: The Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have consistently held that a significant change in the work schedule or living circumstances of a custodial or non‑custodial parent can constitute the requisite material change of circumstances warranting modification.
M.C. v. T.K., 463 Mass. 226 (2012).support_reasoning: This opinion concerns the standard for setting and calculating child support in a shared physical custody situation, particularly the impropriety of income equalization and the application of Child Support Guidelines above the presumptive income cap. It does not address modification standards, material change of circumstances, or changes in work schedules or living circumstances as grounds for modifying existing orders. Because the case neither discusses nor establishes rules about what constitutes a material change warranting modification, it does not support the claimed proposition.
M.C. v. T.K., 463 Mass. 226 (2012).relevant_excerpt: "On remand, the judge is not required to revisit the issue of the father’s income at the time of trial, but should consider whether the circumstances have materially changed since the date of the judgment before us, and should base any award of child support on the parties’ current incomes." (The opinion mentions material change only in passing and without articulating any rule about changes in work schedule or living circumstances.)

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: The Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have consistently held that a significant change in the work schedule or living circumstances of a custodial or non‑custodial parent can constitute the requisite material change of circumstances warranting modification.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: Hunter v. Rose is not a modification case and does not discuss the standard of a ‘material change of circumstances’ for modifying custody or support orders. The passages on work schedules and living circumstances appear only as factors in an initial best‑interests custody determination, not as a basis for modification after a prior judgment. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the proposition that a significant change in a parent’s work schedule or living circumstances can constitute the requisite material change warranting modification.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “Factors a judge may weigh are whether one parent’s home is more stable in terms of a parent’s work schedule, whether siblings are being raised together, and whether one parent seeks to undermine the relationship a child has with the other parent. See Adoption of Kali, supra at 843, 847 (stability and flexible work schedule); … Haas v. Puchalski, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 555, 557 (1980) (denial of custody where home was not ‘settled’ and child would be cared for by multiple providers rather than parent).”

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.proposition: In addition, Massachusetts law requires that the “paramount concern” in any custody or parenting‑time determination be the best interests of the child.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses what factors must be considered in custody determinations—particularly the impact of domestic violence—and references statutory requirements for written findings when there is a 209A order, but it does not state or restate the general Massachusetts standard that the "paramount concern" in any custody or parenting-time determination is the best interests of the child. The phrase "best interests of the child" appears only in a quoted recommendation from the Gender Bias Study and not as the court’s own articulation of the governing test. Accordingly, this case does not clearly serve as authority for the specific proposition claimed.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.relevant_excerpt:
The Appeals Court based its remand to the Probate Court on the failure of that court to make findings regarding the evidence that the father had physically abused the mother throughout the relationship and the effect of this abuse on the *595child.8 The Appeals Court gave great weight to this courts Gender Bias Study of the Court System of Massachusetts (1989) and particularly to the recommendation in that study that,

The legislature and/or appellate courts should make it clear that abuse of any family member affects other family members and must be considered in determining the best interests of the child in connection with any order concerning custody.

*Care & Protection of Three Minors*, 392.proposition: In addition, Massachusetts law requires that the “paramount concern” in any custody or parenting‑time determination be the best interests of the child.
*Care & Protection of Three Minors*, 392.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly frames the dispositional phase of a care-and-protection/custody case in terms of determining which placement is in the children’s best interests, and it quotes G.L. c. 119, § 26, which authorizes the judge to make custody orders "as may conduce to [the child’s] best interests." The court further states that parental fitness and best interests are intertwined tests and criticizes the lower court for failing to make findings that adequately address the children’s best interests in placement and visitation. This aligns with the proposition that Massachusetts law makes the child’s best interests the paramount concern in custody/parenting-time decisions.
*Care & Protection of Three Minors*, 392.relevant_excerpt: This court has said that the “parental fitness” test and the “best interests of the child” test are not mutually exclusive, but rather “reflect different degrees of emphasis on the same factors.” ... In this case, the judge’s task was not complete once he had determined that the mother should not have custody of her children. Also, he should have addressed the various placement options which would further the children’s best interests... [G.L. c. 119, § 26] provides that [the judge may] “make any other appropriate order with reference to the care and custody of the child as may conduce to his best interests.”
